Because of the near approach of
examination time, the Hopkins committee engaged in the work of helping to relieve the suffering incident
to the war in Europe, has been unable as yet to accomplish much in
the direction of arousing enthusiasm in their cause at the University. Some contributions, however, have already been received,
and many inquiries have been made
by students interested in the proposed movement. Plans for inaugurating an enthusiastic and general
campaign immediately after the
holidays are already being made.
While it is unfortunate that the
interest aroused in the question of
bandage-rolling and Belgian relief
should be in a measure dissipated
by the intervention of the Christmas vacation, those who are chiefly
interested in She work are by no
means discouraged at the outlook
for a successful campaign. Surely
no better time could be found for
consideration and action in regard
to the matter than the beginning of
a new term, and this, too, the second term, when the shadow of Final Examinations has not yet darkened the horizon. If anything at
all can be accomplished at Hopkins
to further the splendid work that
is being done in this country to
alleviate the suffering prevalent
abroad, it can be best accomplished
in the few weeks immediately succeeding the holidays.
There is one way, however, in
which some of the students at the
University can be of material assistance at the present time. Mr.
Orlando Harrison, owner of a large
nursery at Berlin, Md., has contributed five hundred Christmas trees
to the Belgian Relief Fund, and
these will be put on sale on December 14 in the place surrounding the
Lyric Theatre. The proceeds from
the sale will be devoted to the cause
of assisting the sufferers abroad.
Thus a great many people in the
city will be able to contribute to
the fund without the slightest inconvenience of any kind.
In the meantime, the committee
whose names were given in the last
edition of THE NEWS-LETTER will
be ready to receive contributions of
money or clothing, or to take the
names of volunteers for the bandage-rolling work, which will begin
directly after Christmas. Any interest displayed by the students at
the University in one or all of the
branches of the campaign that have
been detailed will be greatly appreciated by the committee as a
whole.

BOB LAYFIELD

INDEPENDENT SWIMMING TEAM

THE POWER-HOUSE PROGRESSING

Will Practice in Y. M. C. A. Pool and
Will Make a Schedule—Rowland
is Acting Captain.

Work on New Technical and Heat and
Electrical Supply Building at Homewood Is Nearly Finished.

The independent swimming team
of the University is making rapid
"strokes" toward a successful season. Quite a number of candidates
have turned out, and many more
are expected. Those men who have
already signified their intention are
as follows: Rowland, Brinton, R.
Woodward, A. Randall, Fulton,
Hoffman, Nicholson, Primrose,
Eiseman, Jacobson, Thurman and
Egerton. Rowland, who, is captain
pro tem., urges all men who can
either swim or dive to give him
their names as soon as possible.
Letters arranging for dual meets
during the winter with Navy and
the University of Pennsylvania have
been written, and it is hoped that
an open meet, similar to the annual
Fifth Regiment Armory track meet,
can be arranged as a wind-up for
this year. In these meets men will
be entered in all the events and relay races competed in by teams of
four will be the drawing cards.
Captain Rowland stated that the
pool of the Young Men's Christian
Association had „been secured for
the use of the team. This pool is
seventy-five feet long by thirty feet
wide and is considered one of the
best in the State. The hours at
which the pool is open to Hopkins
swimmers are: Tuesdays, from 8
P. M. to 9 P..M.; Saturdays, from
11.30 A. M. to 12.30 P. M. These
hours, of course, are rather short
just noW, but it is thought that later
on more practices may be held
weekly.
Jeff Brinton, who was a member
of the Princeton water polo team,
will be a swimmer with the independents and will try to get them to
organize a Hopkins tank polo team.
The candidates held an organization meeting on Friday in McCoy
Hall.

During the past week great
changes have taken place in the
power-house at Homewood. The
steady whirr of the turbines and the
slower buzz of the reciprocating engines as they are running the generators on the first tests are a familiar sound.
By the end of this week these
preliminary tests will be over and
the new buildings will receive their
light as well their heat from the
power-house.
But the engine-room is not the
only part of the plant where things
are going on. In the boiler-room
the floor has been laid, scales for
weighing the coal when running on
tests have been installed and the
superheater completed. The only
thing which is not finished here is
the ash-hoist.
In the pump-room the floor has
also been laid and with the removal
of the workmen and the placing of
packing on the pipes it has assumed
a neat appearance, something which
would have seemed impossible a
month ago.
In the room adjoining the pumproom the foundation for the Diessel
engine has been completed and the
big Austrian power producer will
be erected as soon as the masonry
acquires sufficient hardness.
The time for the students to visit
the power-house is short. Soon
everything will be "covered up," so
to speak, and it will be an impossibility to. obtain the insight into the
mechanical details which is now
offered.

JAS. H. DOWNS

subject and presents the course so
that it may be grasped as a whole.
The reasons for holding the
examinations during the weeks immediately preceding the Christmas,
Easter and summer vacations is
perhaps more generally understood.
For surely the feeling that at the
close of the holidays the ordeal of
a test in several studies was awaiting him would make the happiness
of the undergraduate equal to that
of Damocles, who was constantly
aware, even in the height of revelry,
that a sword was suspended over
his head by a hair. Then, too, under such conditions there would be
no time for rest after the strenuous
week, for the work of the next
term would begin immediately.
Surely it is infinitely better to
have, as Hopkins students have at
present, in the deepest gloom the
promise of an approaching morrow
and, after the pilgrimage through
the heat of the desert, the certainty
of a sojourn in the Land of Promise.
It is to be hoped that these somewhat elaborate figures may not have
frightened away the timid freshman, as it is to him that this last
paragraph, filled with unwelcome
advice, is particularly addressed.
Notices of examinations are always
Published a week in advance of the
fateful trysting-hour, and this week
is commonly spent in solitude,
marked by much meditation and
burning of the midnight oil. The
time thus spent in preparation will
in every case prove ultimately to
have been well invested, and will
be of more substantial and lasting
service than many hours of speculation and useless regret after the
ordeal is over.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 14, 1914.

Examinations.

Once more the fateful pine tables
are being prepared, the ink-wells
_cleaned and filled and the neat
papers of questions printed for the
use of despondent undergraduates.
Once more a holy calm pervades
McCoy Hall and the laboratory
buildings of the University and
even those who have not seen Salvation Army Santas posted on every
down-town corner feel in some unaccountable fashion that Christmas
is approaching. Once more the
season of examinations has descended upon Johns Hopkins.
Rumor and speculation are rife.
Upper classmen are noticeably melancholy, freshmen obviously afraid.
Advice is being given on every side
•to men too busy or too nervous to
heed or hear it. Surely, then, in
the midst of this general confusion a few words on the examination system will be neither untimely nor out of place.
First of all as to the object of
the system. The examinations,
which come at the end of every
term, are intended not only to give
the instructor definite information
as to the knowledge of his subject
possessed by any particular student,
but also to review and sum up for
the latter the work done during the
term. Monthly tests, it has been
found, tend to obscure the continuity of the course and fill the minds
of students with scraps of disconnected information. The system in
practice at Hopkins, on the other
hand, makes clear the connection
between the different parts of a

President Goodnow's Recent Lectures.

President Goodnow spoke at
Princeton on Thursday before the
International Polity Club on "The
Work of the Y. M. C. A. at Pekin."
He showed an intimate knowledge of this Y. M. C. A. and gave
members of the club, which is an
undergraduate organization, a very
interesting talk.
Dr. Goodnow was entertained at
the home of Professor McElroy,
the head of the department of history and politics of Princeton. He
returned to Baltimore Friday morning.
• On Friday evening, in McCoy
Hall, the president had the pleasure
of introducing Dean'James E. Russel, of Teachers' College, Columbia
University, when Dean Russel gave
a talk to the members of several of
the teachers' clubs of Maryland on
the subject of "German Education:
Its Present Significance to American Teachers."
Last Tuesday Dr. Goodnow was
the guest of honor and principal
speaker at a meeting of the Baltimore Chapter of the American Institute of Banking in the Calvert
Building. He gave a very instructive talk on "Conditions in China,"
dealing with the financial status of
that fast-awakening country.

11

A PLEA FOR A COURSE IN ART

A plea for a course in Political
Science has already appeared in
these columns. There is, however,
another course, perhaps, equally
important, which ought to be inaugurated. A course in Art, including painting, sculpture, and
architecture, such as is offered in
most universities, large and small,
throughout the country, is needed
at Johns Hopkins University. It
is needed that the Hopkins graduate may be more highly cultured
and broader minded.
Brown, for instance, offers no
less than six undergraduate art
courses. Smith, also about the size
of Hopkins, has a number, with five
art professors, while Harvard has
over ten courses in the Fine Arts
alone, all open to undergraduates.
Michigan, among the Western colleges, has five courses on the History of Architecture, and many
others under the direction of the
Department of Engineering.
There are few men who do not
sooner or later feel the need for a
knowledge of art. An acquaintance
with those who are respectfully
called the "Old • Masters" is as
necessary to the well-bred man as
is a knowledge of history, or, in
fact, literature. Even as drawing
preceded writing in the growth of
man, so today, the love of the beautiful is present in the most uneducated classes. It is not the lack
of an esthetic taste, but the fact
that it is uncultivated, that permits
the "eye-sores" of the modern city.
The study of the Classics is fine, yet
the study of a Greek temple will lay
bare the soul of the people as much
as a drama of Euripides.
But how may such a course be
introduced at Hopkins? There are
two methods. First and best, to
procure a new man who could conduct the new department. Or second, to use the material which we
already have. This latter method
would be almost as efficient, since
among the faculty there are a number who are authorities on different
phases of the subject. The course
might well be divided into five
parts, under as many professors.
The Art and Architecture of the
Orient would come under the direction of the Oriental Seminary; that
of Greece and Rome under the
Classical Department; to the Historical and Romance Departments
would fall the instruction in Gothic
and Renaissance Art. In this manner the course might be introduced,
and later, when proof had been
made of the student interest, then
a separate department could be
founded.
G. F. LUDINGTON.

ELEVATOR MAN AT TEXAS
WEARS GERMAN IRON CROSS

Two veterans of the FrancoPrussian War are at present in the
employment of the University of
Texas. August Nehring, elevator
man in the main building, and Hoffman, head carpenter of the university, were in the German army when
the memorable march on Paris was
made.
Nehring- is a veteran of several
wars. He saw his first action in the
war between Germany and Denmark. Because of marked bravery
in the Schlesswig-Holstein encounters, he was rewarded with four
medals. Two of these were silver
and the other two bronze. In the
following war with Austria he was
again rewarded with his fifth medal.
It was in the Franco - Prussian
War in 1870-71 that he received his
sixth and seventh medals—the last
one being the Iron Cross, so highly
prized by the Emperor's troops.
This cross carries with it a pension
of twenty-five dollars a month, but
when Nehring came to America the
pension was canceled.

ADVOCATES ALUMNI ADVISERS

COLLEGE LIFE AT HOMEWOOD

Athletic Board Member Gives Reasons
Why Amendment to Section II of
Constitution Should Be Passed.

Professors Brush and Bliss, in Alumni
Magazine, Tell of Plans for Dormitory Life at New University.

Loyalty to such a community
would afford a desirable substitute
for class feeling and fraternity
rivalry. In order to secure the
healthy emulation necessary to the
development of such sentiments, it
is essential that from the beginning
separate housing be provided for at
least two communities. The residence of each community should
include not only comfortable bedrooms and studies, but also a common room and dining hall which
should be dignified apartments,
similar to English colleges.
Residence is such an essential
part of university education that
measures should be taken to induce
an overwhelming majority of the
students to live in the University
halls. Such measures may be distinctions in eligibility for athletic
or other teams, for scholarships or
fellowships; or a reduction of the
tuition fee; or a slight dimunition
in the number of courses offered
for graduation. The assignment of
rooms and the fixing of rentals and
price of board should be in the
hands of the University, and especial care should be taken to allow no differences to arise between
communities based on pecuniary or
social distinctions.

5
The success of such a plan depends upon the co-operation of all
of the student body, and the rooming or boarding of undergraduates
in fraternity houses would be fatal
to it. Recognizing, however, the
advantages of membership in wellconducted social clubs, the committee recommended that sites for
meeting rooms or lodges be assigned these various organizations
on the University grounds. There
should also be a building for general student activities, for the
Christian Association, musical and
chess clubs, and college publications, and it might also include a
study room and a lunch room for
those who find it impossible to take
up residence in the halls.
The committee hoped that by providing in this way pleasant and comfortable surroundings there would
develop of itself a healthy atmosphere in the college life which
would make the graduate of the
Johns Hopkins University known
wherever he might go for his
broadmindedness and generally sensible view of life.—M. P. Brush,
collegiate professor of French, and
W. J. A. Bliss, collegiate professor
of physics, in Johns Hopkins Alumni Alagaz.iite.

PAPA'S DARLING

Dean James E. Russel, of the
Teachers' College, Columbia University, delivered a very interesting lecture Friday night in McCoy Hall on "German Education:
Its Present Significance to American Teachers." The lecture was
under the auspices of the Teachers'
College Club of Maryland, the Educational Society of Baltimore and
the faculty of the Teachers' Training School.
The entire lecture was a comparison of German and American
methods of instruction, Dr. Russel
claiming that superiority was shown
by the Germans. The German system of education was shown to be
finished and thorough to the last
degree.
The German boy begins his education when he is about five years
old. He does not spend only onefifth of his day in school as do
American boys, he is not merely
heard the recital of what he has
studied as are American boys, he
must give up nearly all of his time
to his schooling and what he learns
is really imparted to him by his
teacher.
Dean Russel greatly praised the
Boy Scout movement, saying that
it was the one hope of American
education. He claimed that unless
military training was ground into
the boys in the course of their
schooling that some day "the entire
American bubble will burst."
A remarkable picture was given
of German universities. These institutions, Dean Russel declared,
are as markedly inferior to ours as
German "gymnasiums" are superior to our high schools. He explained that life at a university in
Germany was really the application

8
CHANGES MADE IN OFFICERS

14, 1914.

DR. ROSE TELLS OF PROPER

OF UNIVERSITY Y. M. C. A.

DIETS AND FOOD ECONOMY

The monthly meetiug,of the,cabmet of the University Young Men's
Christian Association, held on last
Tuesday afternoon, was very well
attended. Perhaps the most important feature of this meeting was
the election of men to fill several
vacancies of the various committees
and offices. Myron E. Bagley, '16,
was elected first vice-president to
succeed John C. Branham who has
withdrawn from the -University.
Paul W. Sutton, r'17, was elected
as successor to Mr. Bagley's former office of second vice-president.
Claude I. Uhler, 'is, was appointed
chairman of the missionary committee. This vacancy was also
caused by Mr. Branham's withdrawal from the University. The
fact that Mr. S. D. Swan and Mr.
E. L. Fox, who composed .the executive council of the Association,
have not returned ,to the University this year necessitated the election of a new council. Mr. H. S.
Willis and Mr. J. E. L. Holmes,
who are both graduate students,
were elected to fill these positions.
Besides these elections, the present condition of the Association was
discussed from every angle. Particular emphasis was placed on
plans for increasing the present influence of the Association on the
general student body; but realizing
that this influence is, in turn, dependent on the interest of the students in the activities of the Association.
' One of the results of the meeting
was the inauguration of a membership campaign. This campaign will
be started sometime in January.
The exact date will be announced
•
later.
A fairly good Audience, composed
mostly of freshmen, heard Dr. Finney's second and closing lecture on
"Hygiene," which was delivered
last Monday afternoon. It is not unusual to say that those who attended
these lectures this year seemed
to appreciate keenly Dr. Finney's
interesting and instructive talks on
such a vital subject. The Association desires to express, through the
columns of TEE NEWS-LETTER, its
appreciation of Dr. Finney's favors.
Dr. Walter F. Shenton will lead
the chapel services this week. Owing to the examinations, there will
be only three, or possibly four
services.

A very interesting lecture was
delivered Wednesday evening by
Dr. Mary S. Rose of Teachers'
College, New York, in the physics
laboratory, on "Domestic Science."
Dr. Rose spoke on a phase of
domestic science which is just now
occupying a very prominent position in the public mind, namely,
how to derive' the best nutrition in
the cheapest way possible.
Dr. Rose explained that different
types of mind must be sustained by
different kinds of food—that the
brain of a man who is engaged in
purely mental fields of' action can
be best nourished by one proportion of protein, fat, and fuel material, while the brain of a working man, in the usual acceptance of
that term, requires a diet of an entirely different sort. In her lecture,
Dr. Rose considered chiefly the food
required by the average man of
the latter class.
Different foods are valuable for
different properties. Breakfast foods
and cereals contain a large proportion of carbohydrates; cheese has a
great preponderance of fat, bananas
possess much fuel value. A balance of these properties is essentially necessary in any well regulated
diet,'and Dr. Rose furnished some
very simple and practical suggestions which could be applied in obtaining this balance.
On the score of economy, many
a deep-rooted food-tradition was
given its death-blow. It was conclusively shown that food did not
have to be expensive in order to
be beneficial, but that, on the contrary, many of the cheapest products were also the most whole-

We've Reduced

One of the most startling facts
in the matter of economy in relation to food that was brought out
during the lecture.,*as that it is
not'necessary to nourish A consumptive on milk, as has been commonly supposed, but that the same
valuable materials could be given
him in a diet of bacon.
Although Dr. Rose dealt with
scientific matters, she presented her
subject in terms which were quite
plain, even to the layman. A rather
large crowd attended.

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—TO prove that there can be
worse trials than that of gym which
can be expressed in Kiplingesque
form, I venture to submit the following: '

A stude there was and he sought his
lair,
(Even as you and I!)
With a • sullen brow and a hearty
swear
He vowed to the gods that it wasn't
fair—
While he inked all his fingers and
rumpled his hair,
(Even as you and I!)
Oh, the books we scan and the things
we cram,
And the midnight oil we reek,
Belong to the time that we know has
to come
(And now we wish that it never had
come)—
.
Examination Week.
A stude there was and his hours he
spent
(Even as you and I!)
On books that were borrowed and
notes that were lent,
Though the course didn't follow his
natural bent,
Yet he vowed that he'd pass it, whatever it meant.
(Even as you and I!)

Because of the near approach of
examination time, the Hopkins committee engaged in the work of helping to relieve the suffering incident
to the war in Europe, has been unable as yet to accomplish much in
the direction of arousing enthusiasm in their cause at the University. Some contributions, however, have already been received,
and many inquiries have been made
by students interested in the proposed movement. Plans for inaugurating an enthusiastic and general
campaign immediately after the
holidays are already being made.
While it is unfortunate that the
interest aroused in the question of
bandage-rolling and Belgian relief
should be in a measure dissipated
by the intervention of the Christmas vacation, those who are chiefly
interested in She work are by no
means discouraged at the outlook
for a successful campaign. Surely
no better time could be found for
consideration and action in regard
to the matter than the beginning of
a new term, and this, too, the second term, when the shadow of Final Examinations has not yet darkened the horizon. If anything at
all can be accomplished at Hopkins
to further the splendid work that
is being done in this country to
alleviate the suffering prevalent
abroad, it can be best accomplished
in the few weeks immediately succeeding the holidays.
There is one way, however, in
which some of the students at the
University can be of material assistance at the present time. Mr.
Orlando Harrison, owner of a large
nursery at Berlin, Md., has contributed five hundred Christmas trees
to the Belgian Relief Fund, and
these will be put on sale on December 14 in the place surrounding the
Lyric Theatre. The proceeds from
the sale will be devoted to the cause
of assisting the sufferers abroad.
Thus a great many people in the
city will be able to contribute to
the fund without the slightest inconvenience of any kind.
In the meantime, the committee
whose names were given in the last
edition of THE NEWS-LETTER will
be ready to receive contributions of
money or clothing, or to take the
names of volunteers for the bandage-rolling work, which will begin
directly after Christmas. Any interest displayed by the students at
the University in one or all of the
branches of the campaign that have
been detailed will be greatly appreciated by the committee as a
whole.

INDEPENDENT SWIMMING TEAM

THE POWER-HOUSE PROGRESSING

Will Practice in Y. M. C. A. Pool and
Will Make a Schedule—Rowland
is Acting Captain.

Work on New Technical and Heat and
Electrical Supply Building at Homewood Is Nearly Finished.

The independent swimming team
of the University is making rapid
"strokes" toward a successful season. Quite a number of candidates
have turned out, and many more
are expected. Those men who have
already signified their intention are
as follows: Rowland, Brinton, R.
Woodward, A. Randall, Fulton,
Hoffman, Nicholson, Primrose,
Eiseman, Jacobson, Thurman and
Egerton. Rowland, who, is captain
pro tem., urges all men who can
either swim or dive to give him
their names as soon as possible.
Letters arranging for dual meets
during the winter with Navy and
the University of Pennsylvania have
been written, and it is hoped that
an open meet, similar to the annual
Fifth Regiment Armory track meet,
can be arranged as a wind-up for
this year. In these meets men will
be entered in all the events and relay races competed in by teams of
four will be the drawing cards.
Captain Rowland stated that the
pool of the Young Men's Christian
Association had „been secured for
the use of the team. This pool is
seventy-five feet long by thirty feet
wide and is considered one of the
best in the State. The hours at
which the pool is open to Hopkins
swimmers are: Tuesdays, from 8
P. M. to 9 P..M.; Saturdays, from
11.30 A. M. to 12.30 P. M. These
hours, of course, are rather short
just noW, but it is thought that later
on more practices may be held
weekly.
Jeff Brinton, who was a member
of the Princeton water polo team,
will be a swimmer with the independents and will try to get them to
organize a Hopkins tank polo team.
The candidates held an organization meeting on Friday in McCoy
Hall.

During the past week great
changes have taken place in the
power-house at Homewood. The
steady whirr of the turbines and the
slower buzz of the reciprocating engines as they are running the generators on the first tests are a familiar sound.
By the end of this week these
preliminary tests will be over and
the new buildings will receive their
light as well their heat from the
power-house.
But the engine-room is not the
only part of the plant where things
are going on. In the boiler-room
the floor has been laid, scales for
weighing the coal when running on
tests have been installed and the
superheater completed. The only
thing which is not finished here is
the ash-hoist.
In the pump-room the floor has
also been laid and with the removal
of the workmen and the placing of
packing on the pipes it has assumed
a neat appearance, something which
would have seemed impossible a
month ago.
In the room adjoining the pumproom the foundation for the Diessel
engine has been completed and the
big Austrian power producer will
be erected as soon as the masonry
acquires sufficient hardness.
The time for the students to visit
the power-house is short. Soon
everything will be "covered up," so
to speak, and it will be an impossibility to. obtain the insight into the
mechanical details which is now
offered.

subject and presents the course so
that it may be grasped as a whole.
The reasons for holding the
examinations during the weeks immediately preceding the Christmas,
Easter and summer vacations is
perhaps more generally understood.
For surely the feeling that at the
close of the holidays the ordeal of
a test in several studies was awaiting him would make the happiness
of the undergraduate equal to that
of Damocles, who was constantly
aware, even in the height of revelry,
that a sword was suspended over
his head by a hair. Then, too, under such conditions there would be
no time for rest after the strenuous
week, for the work of the next
term would begin immediately.
Surely it is infinitely better to
have, as Hopkins students have at
present, in the deepest gloom the
promise of an approaching morrow
and, after the pilgrimage through
the heat of the desert, the certainty
of a sojourn in the Land of Promise.
It is to be hoped that these somewhat elaborate figures may not have
frightened away the timid freshman, as it is to him that this last
paragraph, filled with unwelcome
advice, is particularly addressed.
Notices of examinations are always
Published a week in advance of the
fateful trysting-hour, and this week
is commonly spent in solitude,
marked by much meditation and
burning of the midnight oil. The
time thus spent in preparation will
in every case prove ultimately to
have been well invested, and will
be of more substantial and lasting
service than many hours of speculation and useless regret after the
ordeal is over.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 14, 1914.

Examinations.

Once more the fateful pine tables
are being prepared, the ink-wells
_cleaned and filled and the neat
papers of questions printed for the
use of despondent undergraduates.
Once more a holy calm pervades
McCoy Hall and the laboratory
buildings of the University and
even those who have not seen Salvation Army Santas posted on every
down-town corner feel in some unaccountable fashion that Christmas
is approaching. Once more the
season of examinations has descended upon Johns Hopkins.
Rumor and speculation are rife.
Upper classmen are noticeably melancholy, freshmen obviously afraid.
Advice is being given on every side
•to men too busy or too nervous to
heed or hear it. Surely, then, in
the midst of this general confusion a few words on the examination system will be neither untimely nor out of place.
First of all as to the object of
the system. The examinations,
which come at the end of every
term, are intended not only to give
the instructor definite information
as to the knowledge of his subject
possessed by any particular student,
but also to review and sum up for
the latter the work done during the
term. Monthly tests, it has been
found, tend to obscure the continuity of the course and fill the minds
of students with scraps of disconnected information. The system in
practice at Hopkins, on the other
hand, makes clear the connection
between the different parts of a

President Goodnow's Recent Lectures.

President Goodnow spoke at
Princeton on Thursday before the
International Polity Club on "The
Work of the Y. M. C. A. at Pekin."
He showed an intimate knowledge of this Y. M. C. A. and gave
members of the club, which is an
undergraduate organization, a very
interesting talk.
Dr. Goodnow was entertained at
the home of Professor McElroy,
the head of the department of history and politics of Princeton. He
returned to Baltimore Friday morning.
• On Friday evening, in McCoy
Hall, the president had the pleasure
of introducing Dean'James E. Russel, of Teachers' College, Columbia
University, when Dean Russel gave
a talk to the members of several of
the teachers' clubs of Maryland on
the subject of "German Education:
Its Present Significance to American Teachers."
Last Tuesday Dr. Goodnow was
the guest of honor and principal
speaker at a meeting of the Baltimore Chapter of the American Institute of Banking in the Calvert
Building. He gave a very instructive talk on "Conditions in China,"
dealing with the financial status of
that fast-awakening country.

11

A PLEA FOR A COURSE IN ART

A plea for a course in Political
Science has already appeared in
these columns. There is, however,
another course, perhaps, equally
important, which ought to be inaugurated. A course in Art, including painting, sculpture, and
architecture, such as is offered in
most universities, large and small,
throughout the country, is needed
at Johns Hopkins University. It
is needed that the Hopkins graduate may be more highly cultured
and broader minded.
Brown, for instance, offers no
less than six undergraduate art
courses. Smith, also about the size
of Hopkins, has a number, with five
art professors, while Harvard has
over ten courses in the Fine Arts
alone, all open to undergraduates.
Michigan, among the Western colleges, has five courses on the History of Architecture, and many
others under the direction of the
Department of Engineering.
There are few men who do not
sooner or later feel the need for a
knowledge of art. An acquaintance
with those who are respectfully
called the "Old • Masters" is as
necessary to the well-bred man as
is a knowledge of history, or, in
fact, literature. Even as drawing
preceded writing in the growth of
man, so today, the love of the beautiful is present in the most uneducated classes. It is not the lack
of an esthetic taste, but the fact
that it is uncultivated, that permits
the "eye-sores" of the modern city.
The study of the Classics is fine, yet
the study of a Greek temple will lay
bare the soul of the people as much
as a drama of Euripides.
But how may such a course be
introduced at Hopkins? There are
two methods. First and best, to
procure a new man who could conduct the new department. Or second, to use the material which we
already have. This latter method
would be almost as efficient, since
among the faculty there are a number who are authorities on different
phases of the subject. The course
might well be divided into five
parts, under as many professors.
The Art and Architecture of the
Orient would come under the direction of the Oriental Seminary; that
of Greece and Rome under the
Classical Department; to the Historical and Romance Departments
would fall the instruction in Gothic
and Renaissance Art. In this manner the course might be introduced,
and later, when proof had been
made of the student interest, then
a separate department could be
founded.
G. F. LUDINGTON.

ELEVATOR MAN AT TEXAS
WEARS GERMAN IRON CROSS

Two veterans of the FrancoPrussian War are at present in the
employment of the University of
Texas. August Nehring, elevator
man in the main building, and Hoffman, head carpenter of the university, were in the German army when
the memorable march on Paris was
made.
Nehring- is a veteran of several
wars. He saw his first action in the
war between Germany and Denmark. Because of marked bravery
in the Schlesswig-Holstein encounters, he was rewarded with four
medals. Two of these were silver
and the other two bronze. In the
following war with Austria he was
again rewarded with his fifth medal.
It was in the Franco - Prussian
War in 1870-71 that he received his
sixth and seventh medals—the last
one being the Iron Cross, so highly
prized by the Emperor's troops.
This cross carries with it a pension
of twenty-five dollars a month, but
when Nehring came to America the
pension was canceled.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, DECEMBER 14, 1914.

ADVOCATES ALUMNI ADVISERS

COLLEGE LIFE AT HOMEWOOD

Athletic Board Member Gives Reasons
Why Amendment to Section II of
Constitution Should Be Passed.

Professors Brush and Bliss, in Alumni
Magazine, Tell of Plans for Dormitory Life at New University.

Loyalty to such a community
would afford a desirable substitute
for class feeling and fraternity
rivalry. In order to secure the
healthy emulation necessary to the
development of such sentiments, it
is essential that from the beginning
separate housing be provided for at
least two communities. The residence of each community should
include not only comfortable bedrooms and studies, but also a common room and dining hall which
should be dignified apartments,
similar to English colleges.
Residence is such an essential
part of university education that
measures should be taken to induce
an overwhelming majority of the
students to live in the University
halls. Such measures may be distinctions in eligibility for athletic
or other teams, for scholarships or
fellowships; or a reduction of the
tuition fee; or a slight dimunition
in the number of courses offered
for graduation. The assignment of
rooms and the fixing of rentals and
price of board should be in the
hands of the University, and especial care should be taken to allow no differences to arise between
communities based on pecuniary or
social distinctions.

5
The success of such a plan depends upon the co-operation of all
of the student body, and the rooming or boarding of undergraduates
in fraternity houses would be fatal
to it. Recognizing, however, the
advantages of membership in wellconducted social clubs, the committee recommended that sites for
meeting rooms or lodges be assigned these various organizations
on the University grounds. There
should also be a building for general student activities, for the
Christian Association, musical and
chess clubs, and college publications, and it might also include a
study room and a lunch room for
those who find it impossible to take
up residence in the halls.
The committee hoped that by providing in this way pleasant and comfortable surroundings there would
develop of itself a healthy atmosphere in the college life which
would make the graduate of the
Johns Hopkins University known
wherever he might go for his
broadmindedness and generally sensible view of life.—M. P. Brush,

PAPA'S DARLING

Dean James E. Russel, of the
Teachers' College, Columbia University, delivered a very interesting lecture Friday night in McCoy Hall on "German Education:
Its Present Significance to American Teachers." The lecture was
under the auspices of the Teachers'
College Club of Maryland, the Educational Society of Baltimore and
the faculty of the Teachers' Training School.
The entire lecture was a comparison of German and American
methods of instruction, Dr. Russel
claiming that superiority was shown
by the Germans. The German system of education was shown to be
finished and thorough to the last
degree.
The German boy begins his education when he is about five years
old. He does not spend only onefifth of his day in school as do
American boys, he is not merely
heard the recital of what he has
studied as are American boys, he
must give up nearly all of his time
to his schooling and what he learns
is really imparted to him by his
teacher.
Dean Russel greatly praised the
Boy Scout movement, saying that
it was the one hope of American
education. He claimed that unless
military training was ground into
the boys in the course of their
schooling that some day "the entire
American bubble will burst."
A remarkable picture was given
of German universities. These institutions, Dean Russel declared,
are as markedly inferior to ours as
German "gymnasiums" are superior to our high schools. He explained that life at a university in
Germany was really the application

CHANGES MADE IN OFFICERS

14, 1914.

DR. ROSE TELLS OF PROPER

OF UNIVERSITY Y. M. C. A.

DIETS AND FOOD ECONOMY

The monthly meetiug,of the,cabmet of the University Young Men's
Christian Association, held on last
Tuesday afternoon, was very well
attended. Perhaps the most important feature of this meeting was
the election of men to fill several
vacancies of the various committees
and offices. Myron E. Bagley, '16,
was elected first vice-president to
succeed John C. Branham who has
withdrawn from the -University.
Paul W. Sutton, r'17, was elected
as successor to Mr. Bagley's former office of second vice-president.
Claude I. Uhler, 'is, was appointed
chairman of the missionary committee. This vacancy was also
caused by Mr. Branham's withdrawal from the University. The
fact that Mr. S. D. Swan and Mr.
E. L. Fox, who composed .the executive council of the Association,
have not returned ,to the University this year necessitated the election of a new council. Mr. H. S.
Willis and Mr. J. E. L. Holmes,
who are both graduate students,
were elected to fill these positions.
Besides these elections, the present condition of the Association was
discussed from every angle. Particular emphasis was placed on
plans for increasing the present influence of the Association on the
general student body; but realizing
that this influence is, in turn, dependent on the interest of the students in the activities of the Association.
' One of the results of the meeting
was the inauguration of a membership campaign. This campaign will
be started sometime in January.
The exact date will be announced
•
later.
A fairly good Audience, composed
mostly of freshmen, heard Dr. Finney's second and closing lecture on
"Hygiene," which was delivered
last Monday afternoon. It is not unusual to say that those who attended
these lectures this year seemed
to appreciate keenly Dr. Finney's
interesting and instructive talks on
such a vital subject. The Association desires to express, through the
columns of TEE NEWS-LETTER, its
appreciation of Dr. Finney's favors.
Dr. Walter F. Shenton will lead
the chapel services this week. Owing to the examinations, there will
be only three, or possibly four
services.

A very interesting lecture was
delivered Wednesday evening by
Dr. Mary S. Rose of Teachers'
College, New York, in the physics
laboratory, on "Domestic Science."
Dr. Rose spoke on a phase of
domestic science which is just now
occupying a very prominent position in the public mind, namely,
how to derive' the best nutrition in
the cheapest way possible.
Dr. Rose explained that different
types of mind must be sustained by
different kinds of food—that the
brain of a man who is engaged in
purely mental fields of' action can
be best nourished by one proportion of protein, fat, and fuel material, while the brain of a working man, in the usual acceptance of
that term, requires a diet of an entirely different sort. In her lecture,
Dr. Rose considered chiefly the food
required by the average man of
the latter class.
Different foods are valuable for
different properties. Breakfast foods
and cereals contain a large proportion of carbohydrates; cheese has a
great preponderance of fat, bananas
possess much fuel value. A balance of these properties is essentially necessary in any well regulated
diet,'and Dr. Rose furnished some
very simple and practical suggestions which could be applied in obtaining this balance.
On the score of economy, many
a deep-rooted food-tradition was
given its death-blow. It was conclusively shown that food did not
have to be expensive in order to
be beneficial, but that, on the contrary, many of the cheapest products were also the most whole-

We've Reduced

One of the most startling facts
in the matter of economy in relation to food that was brought out
during the lecture.,*as that it is
not'necessary to nourish A consumptive on milk, as has been commonly supposed, but that the same
valuable materials could be given
him in a diet of bacon.
Although Dr. Rose dealt with
scientific matters, she presented her
subject in terms which were quite
plain, even to the layman. A rather
large crowd attended.

Our large assembly room McCoy
Has made and broke full many a boy;
It's used by the faculty, used by the
boys,
But never by children who play with

How often I've sighed as I came down

And beheld "old Georgie" removing

We'd 'a liked mighty well to dance

he allowed;
I'll thank him myself in behalf of the
crowd.

SOPHOMORE.

Verses on Examination Week.

December 10, 1914.
To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—TO prove that there can be
worse trials than that of gym which
can be expressed in Kiplingesque
form, I venture to submit the following: '

A stude there was and he sought his
lair,
(Even as you and I!)
With a • sullen brow and a hearty
swear
He vowed to the gods that it wasn't
fair—
While he inked all his fingers and
rumpled his hair,
(Even as you and I!)
Oh, the books we scan and the things
we cram,
And the midnight oil we reek,
Belong to the time that we know has
to come
(And now we wish that it never had
come)—
.
Examination Week.
A stude there was and his hours he
spent
(Even as you and I!)
On books that were borrowed and
notes that were lent,
Though the course didn't follow his
natural bent,
Yet he vowed that he'd pass it, whatever it meant.
(Even as you and I!)
